name: (2E)-1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl[(4-chlorophenyl)hydrazono]ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1084
Reason: 1,3-Benzothiazole has a melting point around 106°C. The presence of two carbonyl groups generally increases the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, which can raise it by approximately +10°C each. The chlorine atom introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The phenyl group also contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and pi-pi interactions, estimated at around +20°C. The hydrazono group introduces additional rigidity and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +10°C. The thiazole ring introduces additional rigidity and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +10°C. Summing up these changes: Benzothiazole base (+106°C), two carbonyl groups (+20°C), one chlorine atom (+50°C), one phenyl group (+20°C), and one hydrazono group (+10°C).
